title: no2, crossvalidation
contents:
Cross-validation strategy, comparing predicted versus observed values on exponential scale: \(exp(log(2020/2019))-1\)
For the model validation, we followed the same approach described in Fioravanti et al. (2020). Namely:
for each month (January - April), we stratified the input dataset according to the environment type classification which distinguishes three different station groups: urban, suburban and rural;
within each group, 10% of the stations were randomly sampled in order to define a validation dataset. The remainder of the stations (training dataset) was used to fit the model and the fitted model was used to predict the log(2020/2019) on the validation dataset. Comparing predicted and observed values allows to assess the model performance on unseen data (if the model underfits, overfits or generalizes well).
both the sampling and the estimation process were repeated three times for each month.
Notation
Months (mm in the results)
1: January; 2: February; 3: March; 4: April
Type site (tipo_zona in the results)
U: urban; S: suburban; R: rural
Model stage (stage in the results)
Val: validation dataset; Train: training dataset

title: Analisi esplorativa dati NO2
contents:
Study area
The input dataset contains 200 monitoring stations distributed in 8 regions in the north of Italy, plus Tuscany region in the centre. At the moment of the analysis the NO2 data from Liguria region were not available.
Interestingly, the investigated area features: the Po Valley (Pianura Padana), the northern Italian Alps and the Apennines range.
The Po Valley is an area characterized by intense human pressure, because of high population density, urban sprawl, intensive agricultural practice and livestock management (Pezzagno et al., 2020;Romano et al., 2020). Consequently, high emission levels characterize the Po Valley.
NO2 is a pollutant mostly associated with urban phenomena.


       EMILIA_ROMAGNA FRIULI_VENEZIA_GIULIA             LOMBARDIA 
                   36                    12                    55 
           PA_BOLZANO             PA_TRENTO              PIEMONTE 
                    5                     5                    17 
              TOSCANA           VALLE_AOSTA                VENETO 
                   34                     4                    32 

Input data
The ground NO2 measurements are expressed as µg/m3. Such measurements are mostly concentrated in urban areas (urban 123, suburban 39, rural 38).
The input data belong to the regional Environmental Protection Agencies (ARPA). Data were quality-controlled and aggregated by the Italian Institute for Environmental Protection and Research (ISPRA).
For the study purposes, we restricted our data to those monitoring stations with at least 75% of available data for each month (March-April/January-April…dipende). The resulting dataset was organized as data frames for the R statistical language [R Core Team, 2018] and stored in packages freely available through a dedicated Github repository.
